text:
Welcome to HowToCookThat I am Ann Reardon
and I'm still getting heaps of requests for
a Moana cake!
We fish beyond the reef.

So here is an easy one for you with no fondant
at all, all the decorations are completely
edible.

This week's notification squad shout out goes
to Megan, Allie, Karen, Aminah, Esmee, Wasan,
Amber, Chip's Channel, Kia and Judy.

For your chance at a shout out subscribe to
HowToCookThat, subscribe and turn on the bell

to turn on notifications and write 'done'
in the comments for me.

To make this cake the first thing we need
to do is make up a double batch of my rich
chocolate cake recipe.

And the recipe video for that and all the
details that you need are on the howtocookthat.net
website and I'll link you to that below.

You want to bake that in a loose based round
cake tin with a smaller tin or you could use

a cup in the centre, and to weigh that down
and stop it floating away and to make it a

bit higher I am using a Pyrex dish on top
of that.

Then I'm going to tie some baking paper around
the outside, this is just so if it rises up

above the edges it's not going to overflow
in the oven it's going to stay in the cake
tin.

Bake that and then once it's cooled remove
the paper and use a knife to run it around

the baking tin in the middle and also right
around the outside.

Loosen the outside part of the tin and take
that off.

Then carefully pull the centre tin out just
pushing out with your fingers and lifting

it up at the same time, giving it a wriggle
and take that out of the middle there.

Transfer that onto a cake board and then level
off the top of your cake, using a knife to

make it all nice and even and all the same
level across the top.

Use a serrated knife to cut a small piece
off from around the top of the cake, just

making it more rounded and a bit more wreath
shaped.

And then you want to do the same thing at
the bottom, just use your knife to cut little

chunks, cutting in towards the base so the
base matches the top.

Finally you want to trim around the centre
on the inside to make that slope inwards and
we have our wreath shape.

Make up a batch of buttercream and add in
some green food coloring and any flavouring
of your choice.

Now remember all the recipes on how to make
buttercream are on the website and that link
is below.

Remove some of your frosting and then add
more green colouring and then do that again

so that you end up with
three different shades of green.
Drizzle some simple syrup on top of your cake.

Now simple syrup is just made of equal quantities
of sugar and water and you just heat it up
in the microwave until the sugar is dissolved.

And putting it on the cake just helps keep
the cake super moist.

Now cover the whole cake with the deepest
green colour buttercream that you have, just

a really thin coat just to catch all the crumbs
and to make it easier to do the next step.

Place the rest of your buttercream onto some
plastic wrap, wrap it up from each side and

then make a tube of frosting just squeeze
it to spread it out there, then hold onto

each end and give it a spin to twist up the
ends.

Repeat that with the other two colours then
trim it off close on one side of your tube
just using some scissors there.

Place all of those into a piping bag and using
these 3 different colours is just going to

give us some variation on the leaves instead
of just having the one green colour on the
whole thing.

Begin to pipe some leaves onto the wreath
working your way all the way around until
the whole thing is covered.

Now take some compound white chocolate or
tempered real chocolate and mix in some powdered
food colouring.

Using a leaf that has been washed and dried
really well, paint chocolate onto the back
of the leaf.

And then run your finger along the underneath
to make sure there is no chocolate wrapping

around to the back, then place that on some
baking paper to set.

Repeat that with more leaves then once they
are all set you can just peel off the leaf

back and you end up with a chocolate leaf
with all the veins and pattern from the real
leaf.

To make the flowers simply pipe some little
drops of chocolate that has been coloured
using some red oil based food colouring.

Lift up your baking paper and give it a little
shake and let it run down slightly.

Place another sheet of baking paper over the
top and then using the side of your thumb

flatten out each petal by gently rubbing on
it.

Then roll up the baking paper in a loose roll
and leave those to set.

Once it's set, unroll it slightly and remove
that top layer of baking paper.

And then gently roll back the underneath layer
to release each of those petals off the paper,

being careful because these are super thin
so they're very delicate but it just makes

them look like real petals when they're this
thin.

Make yourself a ring using foil so we can
support our petals and place a dollop of your
green chocolate right in the centre.

Take five of your petals and place them around
in a circle just overlap each one next to

the one before it, all the way back around
until you get to the start.

Continue doing that, making more chocolate
flowers so that you have enough to go around
the whole wreath.

Once the centre of the flowers is set, dust
some powdered food colouring around the centre

to make the deeper colour like you can see
on Moana's wreath.

Tip it upside down and tap your hand to get
rid of any excess powder and there you have
a pretty chocolate flower.

Add them into place gently pressing them into
the buttercream being careful not the break
your petals.

Then add your chocolate leaves around each
of the flowers so that your wreath looks even
more realistic.

You can't wear it of course but you can eat
it ... perfect for a Moana party!

Moana cake was requested by
kitty's life

Sahar
Berry

Gems
Sugar Geek
and lots more lovely people!

Put all your requests in the comments below
make it a great week and I'll see you on Frida...

Oh and here's some more fondant free cakes,
some of my Disney cakes and my latest video.
